sentences: Werner Reinhart (19 March 1884 – 29 August 1951) was a Swiss merchant, philanthropist, amateur clarinetist, and patron of composers and writers, particularly Igor Stravinsky and Rainer Maria Rilke.
section: N/A

sentences: Reinhart knew and corresponded with many artists and musicians of the early-mid 20th century in Europe world, and his Villa Rychenberg in Winterthur became an international meeting point for musicians and writers.
section: N/A

sentences: He was sometimes referred to as "the Winterthur Maecenas".
section: N/A

sentences: Alice Bailly named Werner Reinhart "L'homme aux mains d'or" – the man with the golden hands, and her 1920 portrait of him is called "The Man with the Golden Heart".
section: N/A

sentences: Oskar Kokoschka also painted his portrait in 1947.
section: N/A

sentences: Werner Reinhart inherited his wealth from the Volkart family business, based in Winterthur, which he ran together with his elder brother Georg.
section: N/A

sentences: Reinhart and Hermann Scherchen played a leading role in shaping the musical life of Winterthur between 1922 and 1950, the emphasis being on contemporary music, and they were instrumental in numerous premieres being performed there.
section: N/A

sentences: Scherchen was one of many people whom Reinhart patronised, not least in Scherchen's case because he had to pay alimony to no less than five ex-wives.
section: N/A

sentences: Igor Stravinsky approached Reinhart for financial assistance when he was writing Histoire du soldat (The Soldier's Tale).
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Igor Stravinsky ===

sentences: The first performance was conducted by Ernest Ansermet on 28 September 1918, at the Théâtre Municipal de Lausanne.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Igor Stravinsky ===

sentences: Werner Reinhart sponsored this performance, and to a large degree underwrote it.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Igor Stravinsky ===

sentences: In gratitude, Stravinsky dedicated the work to Reinhart, and even gave him the original manuscript.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Igor Stravinsky ===

sentences: Reinhart continued his support of Stravinsky's work in 1919 by funding a series of concerts of his recent chamber music.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Igor Stravinsky ===

sentences: These included a suite of five numbers from The Soldier's Tale, arranged for clarinet, violin, and piano, which was a nod to Reinhart, who was an excellent amateur clarinetist.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Igor Stravinsky ===

sentences: The suite was first performed on 8 November 1919, in Lausanne, long before the better-known suite for the seven original instruments became widely known.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Igor Stravinsky ===

sentences: Stravinsky dedicated his Three Pieces for Clarinet to Reinhart, in gratitude for his ongoing support.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Igor Stravinsky ===

sentences: Reinhart founded a music library of Stravinskiana at his home in Winterthur.

sentences: In 1919, Rainer Maria Rilke travelled to Switzerland from Munich.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Rainer Maria Rilke ===

sentences: The outward motive was an invitation to lecture in Zürich, but the real reason was the wish to escape the post-war chaos and take up once again his work on the Duino Elegies.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Rainer Maria Rilke ===

sentences: The search for a suitable and affordable residence proved to be very difficult and Rilke lived in various places.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Rainer Maria Rilke ===

sentences: Only in the summer of 1921 was he able to find a permanent abode in the Chateau de Muzot in the commune of Veyras, close to Sierre in Valais.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Rainer Maria Rilke ===

sentences: It was at Muzot, in February 1922, that Rilke, in a storm of inspiration, wrote most of the fifty-five Sonnets to Orpheus and several smaller collections of poems.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Rainer Maria Rilke ===

sentences: In May 1922, after deciding he could afford the cost of considerable necessary renovation, Werner Reinhart bought Muzot so that Rilke could live there rent-free, and became Rilke's patron.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Rainer Maria Rilke ===

sentences: Here Rilke completed his greatest work, the Duino Elegies.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Rainer Maria Rilke ===

sentences: During this time, Reinhart introduced Rilke to his protégée, the Australian violinist Alma Moodie.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Rainer Maria Rilke ===

sentences: Rilke was so impressed with her playing that he wrote in a letter: What a sound, what richness, what determination.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Rainer Maria Rilke ===

sentences: That and the "Sonnets to Orpheus", those were two strings of the same voice.

sentences: And she plays mostly Bach!

sentences: Werner Reinhart was the primary financial supporter of the Théâtre du Jorat, where Arthur Honegger's oratorio Le Roi David premiered, and corresponded with its owner René Morax.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Arthur Honegger ===

sentences: Honegger's Sonatine for Clarinet and Piano (1921–22) was written for Reinhart.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Arthur Honegger ===

sentences: Honegger's Pastorale d’été was played in Berlin on 9 November 1922, conducted by Bernhard Seidmann.
section: == People Reinhart supported and assisted (abridged) == | === Arthur Honegger ===

sentences: This was financially supported by Werner Reinhart, who also urged Honegger to program Horace victorieux, a work he believed to be far more important.

sentences: It was thanks to Werner Reinhart that Anton Webern, who was living in political isolation in Austria, was able to attend the premiere of his Variations for Orchestra, Op.

sentences: 30 in Winterthur in 1943.

== Other associates ==

sentences: Other associates ==
section: == Other associates ==

sentences: Reinhart was also on good terms with Arnold Schoenberg.
section: == Other associates ==

sentences: Schoenberg wrote to Reinhart in 1923: "For the present, it matters more to me if people understand my older works ...
section: == Other associates ==

sentences: I do not attach so much importance to being a musical bogey-man as to being a natural continuer of properly understood good old tradition!"
section: == Other associates ==

sentences: In January 1933, Hans Pfitzner was so bereft of funds that he offered to sell three museum artifacts to Reinhart for the sum of RM1,500.
section: == Other associates ==

sentences: On this occasion, Reinhart did not respond.
section: == Other associates ==

sentences: After World War II, Wilhelm Furtwängler and his wife Elisabeth escaped to Switzerland with the assistance of Ernest Ansermet and were supported financially by Werner Reinhart.
section: == Other associates ==

sentences: In 1920 Albert Moeschinger received a stipend from Reinhart for three years study abroad.
section: == Other associates ==

sentences: It was at Werner Reinhart's personal invitation that Petr Rybar became concertmaster for the Winterthur Orchestra, where he remained for 28 years.
section: == Other associates ==

sentences: He also knew or corresponded with: Volkmar Andreae, Ernest Ansermet, René Auberjonois, Conrad Beck, Alban Berg, Alfredo Casella, Alexandre Cingria, Gustave Doret, Karl Ferdinand Edmund von Freyhold, Alois Hába, Clara Haskil, Hermann Hesse, Karl Hofer, Heinrich Kaminski, Rudolf Kassner, Carl Montag, Paul Müller-Zürich, Charles Ferdinand Ramuz, Ker-Xavier Roussel, Albert Schweitzer, Richard Strauss, Regina Ullmann and Felix Weingartner.
section: == Other associates ==

sentences: The Winterthur Libraries hold musical and literary manuscripts by Beck, Berg, Debussy, de Falla, Franck, Haydn, Hindemith, Honegger, Kaminski, Krenek, Liszt, Frank Martin, Milhaud, Myaskovsky, Moeschinger, Mozart, Müller-Zürich, Ramuz (Histoire du soldat), Reger, Schoeck, Schubert, Richard Strauss, Stravinsky, Weber, Webern and Hugo Wolf.
section: == Other associates ==
